prs.truncated_body:
Support new report type 'evm_streamlined'. #added

This new report type is designed to be as small and optimized as possible to minimize report size and calldata.

Reports are encoded as such:

(no FeedID specified in opts)
```
<32 bits> channel ID
<64 bits> unsigned report timestamp nanoseconds
<bytes>   report data as packed ABI encoding
```

(FeedID specified in opts)
```
<256 bi
```

```
prs.title: Make RegisterFilter operation atomic
prs.truncated_body:
### Description

Changing the behavior of addToIndices to ignore db corruption when detected, instead of aborting the operation is slightly better behavior for the case where it's called by RegisterFilter. Because the filter passed to addToIndices was just successfully inserted into the db, updating the in-memory index to match may fix the corruption issue whereas ignoring it will simply report

commits.message:
Make RegisterFilter operation atomic

Changing the behavior of addToIndices to ignore db corruption when detected, instead of aborting the operation is slightly better behavior for
the case where it's called by RegisterFilter. Because the filter passed to addToIndices was just successfully inserted into the db, updating
the in-memory index to match may fix the corruption issue whereas ignoring it will simply report the problem and leave things in an inconsistent
state.

addToIndices is also called from LoadFilters(). In that context, whether the operation is aborted or not makes no difference: the error happens
if 2 rows with the same name or filter_id have just been read from the filters table. Aborting amounts to setting the in-memory state to match
the first row, while ignoring sets the in-memory state to match the second row. We could go a step further and try to fix the inconsistency
by deleting one of the duplicate rows and keeping the other, but instead we simply log it as a CRITICAL error to avoid erasing potentially important
information which could help someone investigate how the db got into this invalid state.

If we think of the db as the "source of truth" and the in-memory indices as a cache of it, then both of these decisions can be summarized with:
always make sure that the in-memory state matches the latest known db state as closely as possible, rather than changing the db to match what's
in memory.

**Description**

This PR introduces the idea of a "tx plan".
Plans are build on `PlannedTx` instances.

Each such instance has tx-attributes you can depend on, and whose changes invalidate the downstream dependencies.

Each of the tx-attributes can also be programmed to automatically update based on environmental changes. These updates can also be built as `Option` pattern, for reusability.

prs.truncated_body:
Updates OP Deployer to better handle reverts from within the EVM.

- The `revision id 1 cannot be reverted` error is no more. This panic is now caught, and whatever underlying EVM error that triggered it is returned.
- Revert reasons and messages get bubbled up to the `Call` method.
- 4-byte selector errors are caught and added to the `Call` method's error for easier debugging.

In the futur

commits.message:
op-deployer: Improve error behavior

Updates OP Deployer to better handle reverts from within the EVM.

- The `revision id 1 cannot be reverted` error is no more. This panic is now caught, and whatever underlying EVM error that triggered it is returned.
- Revert reasons and messages get bubbled up to the `Call` method.
- 4-byte selector errors are caught and added to the `Call` method's error for easier debugging.

In the future, we can use source mappings to reslve 4-byte errors to their real underlying errors.

prs.title: feat: keyed nonces
prs.truncated_body:
# What ❔

- Support for EIP-4337's [semi-abstracted nonces](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-4337#semi-abstracted-nonce-support)
- Removal of `setValueUnderNonce` and `Arbitrary` account nonce ordering. All ZK chains were queried and no usage of this functionality was found.

## Why ❔

Requiring a single sequential nonce value is limiting the senders' ability to define their custom logic

* ctb: move vm.broadcast into createDeterministic (#14243)

* ctb: Use startbroadcast/stopbroadcast with createDeterministic

This backports https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/14241 onto develop. While deploying the interop contracts we discovered a bug where nonces would incorrectly increase following calls to `createDeterministic`. This is because `vm.broadcast` will broadcast the _next_ call, but `createDeterministic` sometimes doesn't emit a call at all. This means that (in the case of the Sueprchain deployment) the calls to the input contract's `set` method would be called instead. This in turn caused nonces to increase incorrectly.

To fix this issue, this PR updates the Solidity implementation to use `vm.startBroadcast()` and `vm.stopBroadcast()`. This avoids the issue altogether. To prevent further incorrect usages of `vm.broadcast` I also opened https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/pull/14242 which adds a Semgrep rule to check for this case.

In some use-cases, failure to meet preconditions is in itself an error.
For example, when running acceptance tests against a devnet, we
presumably epxect that the acceptance tests should apply.

This change adds support for an environment variable
DEVNET_EXPECT_PRECONDITIONS_MET=1 that will then mark as failed the
tests for which the preconditions are not met by the provided system.
```

```
prs.title: verify: don't dedup bundles
prs.truncated_body:
>   /* Users sometimes send transactions as part of a bundle (with a tip)
     and via the normal path (without a tip).  Regardless of which
     arrives first, we want to pack the one with the tip.  Thus, we
     exempt bundles from the normal HA dedup checks.  The dedup tile
     will still do a full-bundle dedup check to make sure to drop any
     identical bundles. */

prs.title: Add 'fddev gossip' command
prs.truncated_body:
- Adds a standalone gossip run mode using the production gossip tile
- Remove 'fddev spy' (broken)
- Error fd_keyload_load if called with an empty path
- Allow links without a producer or a consumer
- Fix IPv4 options handling in eqvoc tile
- Prevent startup if gossip tile is configured with invalid IP/port
- Error fd_xdp_install if called without listen ports

commits.message:
Add 'fddev gossip' command

- Adds a standalone gossip run mode using the production gossip tile
- Remove 'fddev spy' (broken)
- Error fd_keyload_load if called with an empty path
- Relaxes gossip topology assumptions
- Fix IPv4 options handling in eqvoc tile
- Prevent startup if gossip tile is configured with invalid IP/port
- Error fd_xdp_install if called without listen ports
- Include fdctl and fddev in 'make bin'

# Fix Duplicate Events for Processed Slots

## Problem

The application was experiencing an issue where multiple events could be sent for the same slot under certain conditions:

1. When a slot was processed out of order (e.g., slot 100, then 101, then 100 again), the system would send both a `New` event and an `OutOfOrder` event for the same slot.
2. During concurrent processing of updates
```

commits.message: Show all AlertBox types in E2E page

Show Ledger help links after USBTransportError

On fresh Linux: web wallet and Ledger device can be paired, but then it throws
"USB Transport error: Failed to execute 'open' on 'USBDevice': Access denied.."
when trying to use it. The help links we showed if device can't be paired are
equally useful here too (setup udev rules). So this shows the same help and
reuses its translations.

Show Ledger help links instead of looping UX in extension

Fixes UX loop in extension if Ledger can be paired but can't communicate.
To reproduce:
- fresh ubuntu (no ledger udev rules setup)
- install chrome (not through snap)
- click "Grant access to your USB Ledger"
- connect Ledger device successfully
- re-open popup
- click "Grant access to your USB Ledger" again
- Ledger device already successfully connected
- re-open popup
- click "Grant access to your USB Ledger" again
- ...

Grant access now checks if Ledger can connect after pairing, fails, and shows
a link that includes how to setup udev rules.

prs.title: fixed ecdsa verify method
prs.truncated_body:
**Description**:
Ecdsa pubkey fails to verify messages.
Should verify the sha3 hash instead of the raw message bytes

**Example**:
```go
func main() {
    message := []byte("message")

    k, _ := hiero.PrivateKeyGenerateEcdsa()
    pub := k.PublicKey()

    sig := k.Sign(message)
    ver := pub.Verify(message, sig)

    fmt.Println(ver) // true
}
```
**Checklist**

- [x] Docum

feat: add end-to-end testing framework for Cardano Rosetta API

- Introduced a comprehensive testing suite including multi-input/output transactions, stake operations, and DRep vote delegation.
